text: Hi.
Let´s start this video with a test.

Let's see if you can understand this phrase:
"Oye chico, se me loqueó la troca!"

Ok, if you don't understand it, don't worry,
I'll tell you later what it means.
It is not Spanish, Spanish… it´s Spanglish or ESpanglish,
or as some linguists prefer to call it, US Spanish,
full stop, no need for more tags.
And what are we talking about exactly?
Well, about this popular way of speaking here in the US,
in which people mix words and grammar from English and Spanish,
as in this song that might be familiar to you…

This… let's say “promiscuous” mix of
Spanish and English is already part of the
Latin popular culture in the USA
and it has left a footprint in advertising,
in literature
or in television series.

Now, for a long time speaking Spanglish was
not considered something particularly positive.

Many would regard it as a kind of deformation
from Spanish or as a bad-spoken Spanish.

But contrary to what some people may think,
quite often Spanglish speakers
speak both languages very well.
It's like your brain is split in two parts,
then you say
well if I want to talk of feelings, Spanish.
Or with mi mamá, or whatever.
If I want to talk like work, street, work life, English.
And then suddenly your brain does like ...

What you just heard is called code switching 
or cambio de códigos
and it is a typical feature of spanglish:
constantly moving from one language to another
within the same sentence or conversation.
I for example... do it all the time.

But that act of mixing and twisting languages
with fluency and grace cannot be done by anyone,

and for Latinos, as Spanish speakers are
called in the US,
and like Cuban-American actress Jenny Lorenzo,
that comes out super naturally.

It is estimated that about 70% of young Latinos
in the US express themselves in Spanglish
usually or all the time.

When BBC Mundo asked some Latinos here in 
the U.S. why do they use it,
we found there were two recurrent reasons.
The first, to speak faster.
Because the right word doesn´t come easily or because it is much longer.
Go figure the sentence "se me loqueó la troca!", the phrase from the beginning of the video,

in “correct” Spanish: I was locked out
of the truck with the key inside, I mean ...
And it can also happen that there is no easy or direct translation for whatever you want to say.
How do you say perreo in English?
I don't know, yo creo que es perrear.
Perreal? as Puerto Ricans would say.
In both languages, right? Perrear.
Perrear, let's go perrear.

The other big reason why many latinos told
us they use consciously Spanglish
is to be able to express their hybrid identity.
For me, Spanglish is family, your roots,
your culture, how you identify with your people.

In 25 more years it is estimated that one
of each four Americans
will be of Hispanic origin.

Many like Jenny will belong already to a third
generation of migrants, grandchildren of Latin

Americans who arrived to the USA as adults,
and for these Latinos mixing Spanish and English

is a natural way of expressing themselves
as the bilingual people that they are.
